sentences.literal: Su Qin was a native of Luoyang in the Eastern Zhou.

sentences.chinese: 東事師於齊，而習之於鬼谷先生。
sentences.literal: In the east, he studied in Qi as a disciple and was instructed by Master Guigu of Ghost Valley.
After wandering for several years, he returned home in dire poverty.

sentences.chinese: 蘇秦聞之而慚，自傷，乃閉室不出，出其書遍觀之。
sentences.literal: Su Qin heard their words and was filled with shame. Wounded in spirit, he shut himself in his room and refused to come out. He brought out all his books and studied them exhaustively.

sentences.chinese: 於是得《周書》陰符，伏而讀之。
sentences.literal: He then obtained the Zhou Book of the Hidden Talisman. Lying prostrate, he studied it intently.
He sought an audience to persuade King Xian of Zhou.
They did not believe in him.
He then traveled west to Qin.
But Duke Xiao of Qin had already passed away.
At that very moment, they were executing Shang Yang and hated all debaters. Su Qin was not employed.
He then traveled east to Zhao.

sentences.chinese: 趙肅侯令其弟成為相，號奉陽君。
sentences.literal: King Su of Zhao appointed his younger brother Cheng as prime minister, giving him the title Lord Fengyang.
Lord Fengyang did not favor Su Qin.
Su Qin departed to travel to Yan. More than a year passed before he obtained an audience.

sentences.chinese: 南有碣石、鴈門之饒，北有棗栗之利，民雖不佃作而足於棗栗矣。
sentences.literal: To the south it has the wealth of Jieshi and Yanmen; to the north, the bounty of dates and chestnuts. The people need not till the fields—dates and chestnuts alone suffice them."
